solution_line_template: The trip to the supermarket and back home covers {supermarket_distance}+{supermarket_distance}=<<{supermarket_distance}+{supermarket_distance}={supermarket_trip}>>{supermarket_trip} miles.

The round trip of two miles each before he actually went to the farm covers {partial_farm_leg}+{partial_farm_leg}=<<{partial_farm_leg}+{partial_farm_leg}={partial_farm_trip}>>{partial_farm_trip} miles.
Six miles to the farm and the total mileage is {supermarket_trip}+{partial_farm_trip}+{farm_distance}=<<{supermarket_trip}+{partial_farm_trip}+{farm_distance}={total_mileage}>>{total_mileage} miles.
The truck consumed {initial_gasoline}-{gasoline_left}=<<{initial_gasoline}-{gasoline_left}={gasoline_used}>>{gasoline_used} gallons of gasoline for the total journey.
So, the rate is {total_mileage}/{gasoline_used}= <<{total_mileage}/{gasoline_used}={rate}>>{rate} miles per gallon.
